response.answer_text: I´ll take it as a philosophical question and respond in those terms: There´s the theory that the universe will one day stop expanding, will start contracting, a new big bang will occur, and contraction/expansion will start all over again. …almost as if the universe is breathing. Only that each breath takes a quadrillion of years (or at least a very big number of years). If we zoom in a bit, closer to our galaxy, someday the sun will start to shrink and become a supernova, eating up planet earth. Let´s zoom further in… Before that supernova happens, it´s fairly likely that a big meteor, a supervolcano, an acceleration in global warming, a nuclear war and/or a pandemic outbreak, will cause some major shifts on the planet as we currently know it. Supposedly the sixth mass extinction is already underway caused above all by human activity. My point is that, eventually, all things get destroyed and start anew. So with that said, what is and what is not sustainable/unsustainable and in what timeframe? At the end, all I know is that I´ve been pushing for sustainable development for the last +20 years because I simply don´t like seeing images of drowning polar bears, hungering children, bleached corals, flooded cities, etc. Many of these tragedies are a direct consequence of human activity or are reinforced by human activity. And, they create suffering among many species that simply should not be taking place in that shape and form.

20th century sustainability that tried to retrofit sustainability over the top of existing designs was often expensive. Strategic, regenerative approaches to sustainability in the 21st century are a whole new ball game of business innovation, opportunities and profits. Key concepts driving the regenerative business space Project Drawdown has recently calculated that shifting to an economy that consumes greenhouse gases instead of consuming them will SAVE $74 trillion in costs avoided over the current supply chain status quo. Solutions | Drawdown Global carpet manufacturer Interface saved US$393,000,000 through competitive, strategic sustainability. What do geckos have to do with carpet tiles?  Is that sustainable enough for you? (BTW, Google’s doing a renewable energy startup in geothermal and Apple’s joined The Circular Economy.)
